query: Summarize the discussion about the law as it presently stands.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature, and should be changed to reflect the way in which people behave within society. Currently, there are a range of offences created by the criminal law, going back to the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 in the middle of the century before last, which provide for offences of assault against a variety of people, including, in particular, Acts such as the Children and Young Persons Act 1933, which provides for offences that are specific to children. In that regard, it could be argued that children have fewer rights than adults.

query: What did the meeting talk about the law as it currently stands and how does it protect children?
summary: Barry Hughes introduced that the law as it currently stands today, and specifically in terms of reasonable punishment, did not protect children. However, the Crown Prosecution Service Cymru Wales was working hard to ensure that this was not the case.

query: What did Sian Gwenllian AM say about the spectrum of offending?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM explained that there was a spectrum of offending. At one end, it was relatively white and the other end was relatively black, but in the middle there were shades of grey. Towards one end of the spectrum, they might have repeated smacking, shouting, maybe hitting the child over the head as well. That would be very much towards the serious end. And the absolute other end of this spectrum was one where they decided it's an offence that they think is so serious that it should be charged and brought before a criminal court.

query: Summarize the discussion about the divergence between the law in England and Wales.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there were other offences in Wales that didn't exist in England, but they didn't crop up very often. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, his approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suited both England and Wales. They would issue policy guidance and charging standards to reflect any changes as they arose.

query: What were the implications for implementing the Bill in Wales for that?

Barry Hughes answered that they were quite satisfied that the current guidance code would cover that. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, their approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suited both England and Wales. They would build themselves up to come up with the appropriate guidance according to the circumstances.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before making their final decision?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it would not necessarily be helpful for them to see the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before making their final decision. They would need to work that up as they went along, and they would run a risk of putting the cart before the horse, if they put it like that.

query: Summarize the discussion about out-of-court disposals.
summary: Barry Hughes first explained that there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. The way he saw it was that, clearly, policing's not devolved, the CPS was not devolution, so it would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposals with more clarity about what each one of them involved. Then he explained that the police and crime commissioners could build an infrastructure that provided for a range of out of court disposals. In terms of awareness raising, there was no such duty proposed in this Bill.

query: What did the meeting talk about out-of-court disposals?
summary: Vikki Howells AM asked about the ongoing work exploring diversion rather than prosecution in respect of this Bill. Lynne Neagle AM answered that they were continuing to explore this as an option.

query: What did the meeting talk about creating a body of out-of-court disposals that were specific to this Bill?
summary: Vikki Howells AM asked about how the bill would actually work in practice. Barry Hughes answered that it was primarily a matter for the police, because there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. The way they could see this was that, within Wales, they could build an infrastructure that provided for a range of out- of-court disposals. The police would be responsible for administering and monitoring the disposals, but they would not be responsible to administer the out of court disposals themselves.

query: What did the meeting talk about the unintended consequences?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the unintended consequences would be very limited. There was a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecuted 5 per cent of those in any given year. And, in his experience, the police were much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago, in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions was not a reason not to say that certain behaviour was or was not acceptable.

query: What did the meeting talk about the unintended consequence of looking to meet targets?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the unintended consequence of looking to meet targets. Barry Hughes believed that it was extremely unlikely that they even had referrals that reached double figures on these cases. They were likely to be very limited. In terms of thinking about another kind of unintended consequence, in terms of managing performance and all of the targets that the police need to reach, were they perhaps going to see some people going through the criminal justice system in an inappropriate way and contrary to the interests of the child?

query: What did the meeting discuss about the potential barriers to implementing this proposed law?
summary: There is a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and the criminal law provides a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. Therefore, when they were trying to achieve outcomes, and they all got funded on the outcomes, that became the priority, and sometimes they lost the focus on the skills, which were ultimately what were supposed to be part of the development for employability.

query: What did the Duke of Edinburgh think about the Welsh bac?
summary: The Duke of Edinburgh thought that the Welsh baccalaureate was a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination. query: Summarize the discussion about universities' views on the value of the Welsh baccalaureate.

query: What did Claire Bennett think of the 'what matters' when talking about the articulation of the big ideas?

query: What did the meeting talk about the potential unintended consequences of the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, Wales Government were big supporters of WISERD and the work that they did, and, in fact, they needed more research into Welsh education, not less. Therefore, they found their papers really helpful and help them to inform their work. Closing the attainment gap was a core element of the national mission for education in Wales and they would not proceed with anything that they thought could lead to an exacerbation of an achievement gap.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the curriculum and the well-being of the children?
summary: According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and I believe will have a bigger impact on children who are in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, there would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales. Secondly, excellent teaching. In the end, no education system, whatever its curriculum, could exceed the quality of the people who stood in front of the children day in, day out. Thirdly, good achievement led to good well-being, but poor achievement was also detrimental to a child. Fourthly, it would be important for children to see themselves and their community reflected in what they were learning in schools.

query: What were the lessons being learned from the introduction of their curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first thing to realise is that their curriculum was not a copycat of the Scottish curriculum, but it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that had arisen. Although their curriculum wasn't a copyback, as Kirsty said, they had had people who had been deeply involved in the Scottish experience as part of some of their curriculum and assessment groups and some of the advice had been in terms of developing coherence. Assessment had been a crucial part of the process that they had been involved in.

query: How was the money that was announced for supporting teachers for the preparation of the implementation?

That money was being made available to each and every school and had empowered headteachers to really think, 'What are the professional needs of my school and the practitioners in my school?' Because, as we've just heard from Claire, there were some schools that had been part of the pioneer process from the very beginning and therefore were further along that development chain. There were other schools that maybe were only beginning now, now that it's published, to be really engaging with the curriculum.

query: What did the meeting talk about the professional development preparation?

So, they were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they didn't think they had done that on a consistently good level across the country. They were also involved in—and I'm sure the committee has heard about it, so forgive me if I'm going over old ground—schools as learning organizations and the OECD work to support schools to develop that culture as a learning organisation. There would be an ongoing programme of preparation development and personal development, as well as anything else.
